segments.text: Good morning, Torres and Kim. Ready for prebreathe protocol? Let's get you suited up for today's EVA.
Morning, Commander. I slept well, feeling good. Ready to get outside.
Same here. I've been visualizing the procedure all night. Let's do this.
Good mindset. First things first - oxygen masks on. We need one hour of pure O2 breathing before depressurization.
Mask on. Flow rate feels good. This always makes me a little lightheaded at first.
My mask is secure. I've got good flow. Timer started?
Timer's running. You've got 60 minutes starting now. This purges nitrogen from your blood, prevents decompression sickness.
I know the science, but it still feels weird breathing pure oxygen. Like I'm hyperaware of every breath.
That's normal. Just relax into it. While you breathe, I'll start the suit checkout. Torres, your EMU is number 3012.
And I'm in 3008. We verified all the systems last night, but let's run through it again.
Absolutely. Checking 3012 first. Battery power showing 100 percent charge. That's good for eight hours.
Oxygen tanks at full pressure - 850 PSI. Water cooling system reservoir full. Communications check pending.
All nominal so far. What about the primary life support system backpack?
PLSS showing green across the board. CO2 scrubber cartridge fresh, installed yesterday. Fan motor tested operational.
How's the thermal control? Last EVA, Jenkins reported his suit ran warm.
We recalibrated both units after that incident. Temperature control set to automatic, should maintain 18 degrees Celsius.
Now checking 3008. Battery at 100 percent. Oxygen pressure 850 PSI. Water reservoir full. All systems match 3012.
Commander, quick question - if we need to extend the EVA beyond the planned time, what's our margin?
With full consumables, you're good for seven hours absolute maximum. The repair should take 90 minutes. That gives you massive safety buffer.
That's comforting. Not that I want to be out there for seven hours. Two hours max is my preference.
Understood. Alright, helmet comm check. Torres, can you hear me through the mask?
Loud and clear, Commander. Five by five.
Kim, how's your reception?
Crystal clear. No static or interference.
Perfect. While we wait out the prebreathe timer, let me walk through the translation path one more time.
Exit the airlock, you'll be facing the Z1 truss. The antenna is 30 meters to starboard. You'll use handrails the entire way.
We move together, tethered at all times. Kim manages the safety tethers, I focus on the path.
Every three meters, we leapfrog the tethers. One is always locked before the other releases.
Exactly right. Speed is not important. Smooth, methodical movement. No rushing, no shortcuts.
Once we reach the antenna, I'll assess the bracket damage. If it's just the bolts, straightforward replacement.
And if the mounting plate itself is compromised, you'll photograph it, document the damage, and we'll decide on next steps.
I'll be filming everything with the helmet cam. Ground control will have real-time video for analysis.
Good. Now, let's talk about the sun-shadow transition. You'll be in continuous sunlight for the first 30 minutes.
Then we enter eclipse. The temperature drop is dramatic - your suits will compensate, but you'll feel the shift.
Helmet lights on during eclipse. We practiced this in the neutral buoyancy tank.
The stars come out during eclipse, right? People say it's beautiful.
It is. But stay focused on the work. You can enjoy the view after the repair is complete.
Understood. Work first, sightseeing second. How much time left on the prebreathe?
You've got 52 minutes remaining. Once that's done, we suit up properly. The whole donning process takes about 30 minutes.
Then depressurization, and out we go. I'm ready. A little nervous, but ready.
Nervous is healthy. Overconfident is dangerous. You both have the right attitude for this.
Thanks, Commander. Your confidence in us means a lot.

environment.background_sounds: oxygen flow, equipment beeping, suit rustling
